pathway: Pharmacy First – Otitis Externa (adults and children ≥ 1 year)
notes: Assess pain score, systemic upset, and risk of malignant otitis externa in people with diabetes or immunosuppression.
Only supply topical therapy if the tympanic membrane appears intact and there is no in-situ grommet.
Arrange same-day medical review if symptoms have persisted >3 weeks, if there is a history of radiotherapy to the temporal bone, or if topical therapy has failed within the past month.
Document shared decision-making, ear-care advice (keep ear dry, avoid self-cleaning) and safety-netting for all patients.

decisionTree.title: Presenting features
decisionTree.question: Are there symptoms consistent with diffuse otitis externa?

cardinal: Itchy, painful external ear canal with tenderness when moving the tragus or pinna
Otorrhoea or watery discharge without systemic illness
A feeling of fullness or conductive hearing loss
Recent water exposure, trauma from cotton buds or devices
ruleOut: Recurrent acute otitis media with perforation
Foreign body, impacted wax only, or referred dental/TMJ pain

yes.title: Urgent red flags
yes.question: Does the patient meet ANY emergency criteria?

systemicIllness: Toxic appearance or rapidly spreading cellulitis of pinna/face
Severe otalgia out of proportion to findings
malignantRisk: Diabetes, immunosuppression or older age with granulation tissue
Cranial nerve palsy, trismus or severe nocturnal pain

yes.title: Emergency/same-day referral
actions: Consider NEWS2; refer to A&E/ENT on-call or call 999 for sepsis or necrotising otitis externa.
Do not instil drops if TM integrity uncertain; keep patient nil by mouth if surgical review anticipated.

no.title: Exclusion criteria for pharmacy management
no.question: Does the patient meet ANY exclusion criteria?

criteria: Tympanic membrane perforation, open mastoid cavity or grommet in situ
Recurrent episodes (>3 in 6 months), symptoms >3 weeks or treatment failure within 28 days
History of ear surgery (except grommets) or suspected cholesteatoma
Unilateral hearing loss with persistent discharge in high-risk patients (diabetes, immunosuppression)
Foreign body requiring instrumentation or traumatic injury

yes.title: Same-day referral
actions: Arrange assessment by General Practice, ENT clinic or community ear-care service.
Advise dry ear precautions, simple analgesia and avoidance of inserting objects into the ear canal.

no.title: Ear canal assessment
no.question: Is the canal obstructed by debris/wax or is a wick required?
details: Marked oedema with narrowing preventing drop penetration
Impacted debris obscuring the view of the tympanic membrane

yes.title: Refer for aural toilet
actions: Refer to an ear care clinic, ENT department or GP with microsuction access.
Do not syringe; advise the patient to keep ear dry and commence prescribed analgesia.

no.title: Assess severity
no.question: Choose the best description of the current episode

choices.label: Mild inflammation without oedema or cellulitis

next.title: Acetic acid 2% spray plus self-care

dose.regimen: 1 spray (approx. 0.14 mL) into affected ear every 2–3 hours (max 3 times daily)

plus: Advise to keep ears dry, stop using cotton buds and consider ear plugs for swimming once healed
next.followUp: Return if no improvement within 3 days or sooner if swelling/fever develops

choices.label: Moderate/severe pain or canal oedema but stable

next.title: Topical antibiotic/steroid strategy
next.question: Is aminoglycoside sensitivity or perforation suspected?
details: Check allergy history for neomycin, framycetin or polymyxin
Exclude perforation/grommet again before supplying drops

yes.title: Refer for alternative therapy
actions: Arrange GP/ENT review for ciprofloxacin 0.3% ear drops (off-label) or oral therapy as indicated.
Provide interim analgesia and reinforce ear-care measures.

no.title: Neomycin/polymyxin B/hydrocortisone ear drops
no.drug: Neomycin 3.5 mg/mL + polymyxin B 10,000 units/mL + hydrocortisone 10 mg/mL

dose.regimen: 3 drops into affected ear(s) three times daily after warming the bottle

plus: Consider ear wick insertion if canal remains swollen; review in 48 hours
Teach patient to lie with affected ear upward for at least 5 minutes after instillation
no.followUp: Review after 48 hours; refer if no improvement within 72 hours or if discharge persists beyond 7 days

choices.label: Recurrent episode or significant dermatological component

next.title: Address underlying drivers
actions: Consider allergic, eczematous or seborrhoeic causes; offer emollient around pinna and avoid irritants.
Arrange GP review for dermatology input and potential prophylactic drops.
Safety-net for sudden hearing loss, vertigo or new neurological deficits.

no.title: Consider alternative diagnosis
actions: Assess for acute otitis media, temporomandibular joint dysfunction, dental infection or neuropathic pain.
Provide symptomatic relief if appropriate and signpost to GP if pain persists or new red flags emerge.
